CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6-2 - Charged with a criminal offence)

CARDINAL . NORP In coming to that conclusion , ORG took into account that witness PERSON had made the impression of being authentic . It was true that her statements had been short and she had appeared being relatively uninvolved . However , CARDINAL witnesses who knew PERSON partly for a longer period of time had confirmed that she generally spoke and acted in that manner and did not discuss problems in detail .

CARDINAL . ORG observed , however , that even having regard to these elements , the inconsistencies in witness PERSON ’s statements prevailed to an extent that it was not in a position to establish concrete offences . There were inconsistencies in the witness ’s statements on the number of the acts described by her ( CARDINAL ) , the place of these acts ( notably concerning acts in a holiday apartment which the witness mentioned only at a later stage ) and the time frame in which they took place ( starting when the witness was CARDINAL and ending either on the witness ’s placement in the home or continuing also after that placement ) . Moreover , A. had been uncertain in the hearing about the exact manner in which the acts described by her were committed in the car and did not recall any details on several points . A. had , for instance , been very uncertain in the hearing whether the applicant had moved within the car onto the front passenger seat where she had sat or whether he had left the car and walked around it to come on her seat . Moreover , A. had declared several times in the hearing not to have any precise recollection of the events any more .
